newsitem.title: FRANCE: Steady French wheat prices ignore Chicago fall.
newsitem.headline: Steady French wheat prices ignore Chicago fall.

text.p: French wheat prices were flat on Tuesday, ignoring Chicago's retreat below four dollars a bushel, as nervous buyers and sellers kept apart, traders said.
Buyers were said to be pulling back in the face of lower world prices while sellers were playing it more cautiously.
Rouen-delivered wheat was sought at 860 francs per tonne for October and 855 francs for November-December. January-March suppies were bid at 835 francs.
The prices exclude carrying charges of 3.64 francs per tonne which must be added for every half-month elapsing between August 1 and the delivery period in question.
Traders said prices were edging towards levels that would make it difficult to go further.
Algeria was seeking 75,000 tonnes of extra French or Argentine wheat for November/December shipment, they noted.
There was unconfirmed talk on Tuesday afternoon that Algeria had bought wheat from both countries earlier in the day.
The Chicago Board of Trade's nearby wheat futures contract fell below the key $4.00 per bushel level on Tuesday with the market hit by a hike on Australia's wheat crop forecasts.
December Chicago wheat was trading at $3.96 a bushel, down 4-1/2 cents, near the end of the European business day.
November Matif fob-barge wheat futures in Paris were up 10 francs a tonne at 860 francs on volume of 61 lots.
French cash maize slipped as dry weather allowed the harvest to continue but business was slack, traders said.
Prompt fob Atlantic maize fell five francs to 910 francs.
The national weather service predicted rain for Thursday in western France followed by showers everywhere on Friday.
